Cultivating the path is not shared with others, able to expound the unsurpassed meaning,
Bowing to the principle of the MahÄyÄna, I will now discuss establishment and refutation.
Cultivated by immeasurable buddhas, removing hindrances and the fundamental,
The nature of consciousness-only is tranquil, but inferior people do not believe it.
In the MahÄyÄna, it is established that the three realms are only consciousness. As a sÅ«tra says:
Buddha's disciples!
The three realms are only mind.
Mind, thought, and consciousness, etc. are general names. One should know that this mind has associated dharmas.
The word only is to remove form, objects, etc.
In reality, there are no external objects, because consciousness arises resembling objects,
Just like a person with blurred vision sees hairs, two moons, etc.
In the MahÄyÄna, the principle is established that external objects do not really exist.
If that is so, then how is it that external objects are seen to exist?
In order to prove this meaning, it says because the consciousness resembling objects arises.
Because consciousness appears resembling objects, sentient beings see objects in the absence of objects.

In order to illustrate this consciousness, this analogy is given: just as when the eyes have a disease or the eye faculty is disturbed, the consciousness in the absence of an object appears resembling two moons, a mirage, and so forth.
The meaning of consciousness-only is also like this. Therefore, in the three realms there are in reality no external objects, and consciousness transforms appearing as objects.
The three natures and the two truths are all of the nature of non-nature, called the non-established.
Place and time are all without fixed, without continuity and indefinite,
All actions are not accomplished, if there is only consciousness without objects.
What meaning does this verse intend to illustrate?

If the consciousness of form and so forth arises apart from the six sense objects, and does not arise from the objects, why does this consciousness sometimes arise in a certain place and not arise everywhere?
Within this place, sometimes it arises and sometimes it does not arise, and it does not always arise?
If many people are in the same place at the same time, this consciousness does not necessarily arise in a continuous series, but follows each individual.
For example, when a person with cataracts sees hairs, two moons, etc., others do not see them.
Again, what is the reason that the hairs, flies, etc. seen by a person with cataracts cannot perform the functions of hairs, flies, etc., while other things can?
Also, the food, drink, clothing, poison, weapons, staffs, etc. obtained in a dream cannot perform the functions of food, etc., while other things can.
Also, a gandharva city is actually non-existent and cannot perform the functions of a city, while other cities can.
If they are the same in being without objects, how can these four meanings be different?
Therefore, apart from objects, definite place, definite time, indefinite continuity, and performing functions, these four meanings are all not established.
It is not that the meanings of definite place, etc. are not established, like in a dream.
How is it that in a dream, there are no objects?
In a certain place, one may see a country, garden, men, women, etc., but not everywhere.
Or sometimes it is in the middle, sometimes seen and sometimes not seen, but not always seen.
Therefore, apart from the dust, the fixed place and fixed time can be established.
Like the continuity of hungry ghosts is indefinite, like the continuity of hungry ghosts is not established.
How can it be established?
All equally see the river of pus, etc.
Because the river is filled with pus, it is called a river of pus, just like a jar of ghee.
Because the hungry ghosts are in the same karmic retribution state, all see the river filled with pus, etc., not just one.
Just as they see a river of pus, the other rivers of feces and filth are also like this.
Or they see people holding knives and staves to guard it, not allowing them to approach.
In this way, the continuity of consciousness only is indefinite, and apart from the dust, it can be established, like harming in a dream.
Like in a dream, apart from the union of a man and woman, the sign of harm by the emission of impurity in a dream can be established, and the same is true for actions.
This analogy each illustrates the four meanings of the establishment of place, time, etc.
Furthermore, just as in hell, all are established by the four meanings through the analogy of hell.
How are they established?
Seeing the wardens and experiencing harm together.
Just as the sinners in hell see the wardens and so forth, they see dogs, crows, mountains, and so on in a fixed place and at a fixed time, and they see them equally, not individually.
Experiencing harm is also like this. Although there are no real wardens and so forth, due to the dominant condition of the same karmic retribution, it is the same in other places.
Through this general analogy, the four meanings are established.
Why is it not accepted that the wardens, dogs, crows, and so on are real sentient beings?
Because it is unreasonable.
The wardens are not established as the sinners who experience punishment in the hells, because they cannot experience the suffering of hell.
If the sinners in hell harm each other, how can they be distinguished as this is a sinner in hell and that is a warden?
If they have the same appearance and strength, there is no meaning of mutually fearing each other.
On the ground of red iron, flames always arise. They themselves cannot endure the suffering of burning, so how can they oppress and harm others there?
They are not hell beings, so how can they be born in hell?
How can animals be born in heaven?
In this way, animals, hungry ghosts, and other different kinds born in hell are called jailers, but this is not so.
Just as animals are born in heaven, hell has no mixed paths,
Because they cannot endure the suffering of hell.
If animals are born in heaven, by mixed karma they are able to experience the happiness of the world and in the middle they experience the heavenly blissful retribution.
The jailers and others do not do this, because they do not experience the suffering of hell retribution, therefore it is not reasonable for animals and hungry ghosts to be born in hell.
By the karma of sinful people, they are born resembling jailers and others,
If you allow that they transform, why not allow it for consciousness?

Because of the karmic retribution of the hell beings, the four great elements give rise to various distinctions, such as the wardens of hell, with different appearances, shapes, and sizes, which are called the wardens of hell, etc.
The transformations are also like this. Sometimes they appear to move their hands and feet, etc., causing fear and killing.

Or there are two mountains that resemble rams, sometimes coming together and sometimes separating, and in the forest of iron trees, the sharp thorns of the iron trees are sometimes lowered and sometimes raised. They say this is not nonexistent.
Why not allow that the transformations arise from the mind giving rise to karma, and instead say that the four great elements have these transformations?
Furthermore,ğŸ”½The perfuming of karma within consciousness,
Grasping the result as arising externally,
Why not speak of the result in the perfumed place?
The karma of these sinners can see such things as the aggregation of the four great elements and their transformations in hell.
This perfuming of karma is in the continuity of consciousness of the hell beings, not elsewhere.

This perfuming is the transformation of consciousness appearing as jailers and so forth. It is the retribution of action, but you do not admit that it is born in the place where it is perfumed. You admit that the result of action is born in a place other than where it is perfumed. What reason do you have for this kind of theory?
The reason is the scriptures.

If consciousness is born resembling visible forms, etc., and there are no external objects such as visible forms, the World Honored Buddha should not have said that the various sense bases such as visible forms really exist.
This scripture is not a reason, because it is not the meaning of the scripture.
The sense bases such as visible forms are taught in order to convert people who grasp a self.
Because it is taught according to a specific meaning, just as it is said that the magically created is born.

Just as the World Honored Buddha says that there are magically created sentient beings, he says that the characteristics of the magically created are not severed and continue up to the next life because of a specific meaning.
Moreover, the Buddha says:
There are no sentient beings or selves, only dharmas with causes and effects.
Because of this specific teaching, we know it is a specific teaching.
The Buddha, the World-Honored One, also speaks of the sense bases such as form in the same way, teaching the sense bases to sentient beings who are suitable to hear them and to be liberated.
This is the teaching based on the intention. What is the separate intention?
The consciousness arises from its own seeds, manifesting as if it were an external object.
In order to establish the internal and external sense bases, the Buddha teaches these two.
What meaning does this verse intend to illustrate?

The consciousness that appears as an external object arises from the transformation of its own seeds. These seeds and the manifestation as if it were an external object are the means for the arising of the consciousness that appears as form.

The Buddha, the World-Honored One, sequentially teaches the sense base of the eye and the sense base of form, up to the consciousness that appears as touch arising from its own seeds up to the transformation and differentiation. These seeds and the manifestation as if it were touch are the means for the arising of the consciousness of touch. Therefore, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, teaches them as the sense base of the body and the sense base of touch.
If the sense bases are taught based on this meaning, what benefits are there?
If others rely on this teaching, they can enter into the non-self of persons.
By the separate teaching that can eliminate discrimination, one enters the emptiness of dharmas.
If the World-Honored Buddha teaches the various entrances by this meaning, the disciples who receive the teaching can enter the emptiness of persons.
From the mere six pairs, only the six consciousnesses arise. There is no dharma that is the seer up to the toucher.
If one knows this meaning and speaks of the emptiness of persons, the disciples who receive the teaching can enter the emptiness of the self of persons.
By the separate teaching, by the teaching of mere consciousness one can enter the emptiness of the self of dharmas.
How does one enter the emptiness of dharmas?
All dharmas are born from mere consciousness, appearing as forms, objects, etc. There is not a single dharma with the characteristics of form, etc.
If one knows this, one can enter the emptiness of dharmas.
If all dharmas are completely non-existent, then mere consciousness would also be non-existent. How can it be established?
It is not that all dharmas are completely non-existent and called the emptiness of dharmas. Knowing this meaning is not called entering the emptiness of dharmas.
If so, how can one enter the emptiness of dharmas?
Because the characteristics of the discriminated nature are eliminated, one can enter the emptiness of dharmas.

The characteristics of dharmas as discriminated by ordinary beings are empty of all dharmas and do not exist. This is called the emptiness of dharmas, not because the inexpressible essence of the realm of all buddhas is said to be the emptiness of dharmas.
In this way, consciousness-only is empty because it is discriminated by other consciousnesses and does not exist in essence.
If one enters this principle, one can establish consciousness-only and enter the emptiness of the self of dharmas, not by negating the non-existence of all dharmas.

If it were not so, the separate consciousnesses would become the objects of separate consciousnesses, and the meaning of consciousness-only would not be established, because the objects of consciousness would really exist.
How can this be believed?

For this reason, the World-Honored Buddha said that the sense bases such as form and so forth exist, not because the real sense bases such as form and so forth are the objects of the eye consciousness and so forth.
In this way, this meaning can be believed.
The external objects and the atoms are neither the same nor different,
That aggregate is also not an object, because the atoms are not established.
What meaning does this verse intend to show?
Are these sense bases such as form each the object of eye consciousness, etc., the same as the atoms with parts as the VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas assert?
Or are they not the same, because the atoms are each separate?
Or is it that the sense bases such as form are aggregates of atoms, becoming one as the object of eye consciousness, etc.?
This is not so.

Because this form with parts cannot be seen as different from the parts, and also because many atoms are each not visible, and also because many atoms are not aggregated to form objects, because the atoms do not form a single thing.
How are they not formed?
Six atoms gather together at one time, forming six directions,
If the six are in the same place, the aggregate would be the same size as an atom.
Six atoms come from six directions and gather with one atom.
Because this atom is not a single entity, it has six directional parts.
Because atoms in other directions cannot occupy the same space as this atom.
If the space occupied by one atom is the same as the space occupied by six atoms, then the size of all aggregated objects would be the same as that of an atom, because they do not mutually overlap.
Like the size of an atom, aggregates would also be invisible.
If you say that atoms cannot accumulate because they have no directional parts, this error cannot arise.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas of KaÅ›mÄ«ra say that atoms mutually correspond in their aggregates, but this should be questioned.
As you say, the aggregate of atoms is not different from the atom.
If the atom does not combine, who combines in the aggregate?
Moreover, without directional parts, the atom cannot form an aggregate.
If the atom has no combination, to what dharma does this combination belong in the aggregate?
If you say that atoms can mutually combine,
this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because atoms have no spatial parts.
If combination is not established, how much more so for a nominally existent aggregate?
It should be said like this.
If combination is not established for an aggregate with spatial parts, how can a combination of partless atoms be established?
Therefore atoms do not constitute a single entity.
Whether the combination of atoms is possible or not is not discussed here.
If an entity has spatial parts, it should not constitute a single entity.
The eastern part of an atom differs from the other five directions, and so on down to the lower part.
If the parts are different, and the atom takes the parts as its substance, how can it constitute a single entity?
How can there be shadow and obstruction?
If an atom has no spatial parts, when the sun is rising, how can there be a shadow on one side?
Why ask such a question?
This atom has no separate part that is directly illuminated by the sun.
Moreover, if these atoms are juxtaposed without any intervening space, how can they obstruct each other?
Why is this?
This atom has no other part that can join with another coming atom to create obstruction.
If there is no obstruction, then all atoms in the six directions are in the same place, and all aggregates would be the same size as atoms. This point has already been explained above.
Why not accept that shadows and obstructions belong to aggregates, not atoms?
Do you now accept that aggregates are different from atoms?
Therefore, do you say that shadows and obstructions belong to aggregates? No.
If they are the same, there are no two. If aggregates are not different from atoms,
then shadows and obstructions do not belong to aggregates.
Why is this?ğŸ”½It is only the distinction of form that is called an aggregate. What need is there to make such a conceptualization?
The nature of form and other sense objects has not yet been refuted. What is their nature?
The objects of the eyes and so forth, as well as the categories such as blue, should be considered together.
Are the objects of the eyes and so forth, as well as the categories such as blue, which you hold to be the substance of the sense objects, many things or one thing?
What is wrong with that?
If they are many, the fault is as stated before;
if they are one, there are also errors.
As a verse says:
If they are one, without sequential movement, there is neither attainment nor non-attainment,
and there are also many distinct events, which are subtle and difficult to perceive.
If all blue, yellow, and so forth are without separation, and the objects of the eyes are held to be one thing, then there is no sequential movement on the ground.
If one places the foot down, one should move everywhere.
Here, attainment and non-attainment in that place are not established at the same time.
Why is this?
One thing in one moment should not be both obtained and not obtained. There should not be many different kinds like an army of elephants and horses, nor should there be many different things.
Why is this?
If many things are in the place of one thing, how can the distinction between this and that be established?
Moreover, how can it be one, and the space in between is reached by two?
Furthermore, the most subtle water insects have the same color as the large ones, so there is no meaning of being invisible.
If you grasp the existence of separate things by the distinction of characteristics such as color, etc., not by separate meanings,
then it should definitely be distinguished by the distinction of types of neighboring emptiness, and then neighboring emptiness cannot be one thing.
The five sense objects such as color are not the objects of the eyes, etc., therefore the meaning of consciousness only is established.

The objects refer to the essence of consciousness and dharmas, free from subject and object, thus not increasing or decreasing, without cause or unequal causes, the two emptinesses and the twelve links of dependent origination are precisely their intrinsic nature.
As a verse says:
This exists, this does not exist can be determined based on the various means of valid cognition, among all means of valid cognition, the means of valid cognition of direct perception is supreme.
If objects are truly non-existent, how can such direct perceptual knowledge arise?
Namely, I directly perceive this.
Direct perceptual knowledge is like in a dream.
Just as in a dream, apart from the objects, one sees the colors of mountains, trees, and so forth, without external objects.
Direct perceptual knowledge is also like this.
At that time, as direct perceptual knowledge, at that time one does not see objects.
How can objects be directly perceived?
As you say, when direct perceptual knowledge arises, one thinks I directly perceive this.
At this time, you cannot perceive the object, but only the mental consciousness distinguishes it, because the eye consciousness has already ceased. How can the object be cognized?
If someone says it perishes in a moment, this person grasps form and so on up to touch as having already ceased.
Question:
If it is not measured by the five consciousnesses, the mind cannot remember it. Therefore, the five objects are definitely measured by the five consciousnesses.
Measurement is called seeing. Therefore, form and so on, the six objects, are said to be what is cognized.
Answer:
This is not so, namely, the object is cognized first, and then it is remembered.
Why is it so?
As it is said, consciousness resembles the object.
Apart from the six objects such as form, the six consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness arise resembling the six objects.
This meaning is as explained above.
From this, memory arises.

From this, there arises a consciousness similar to the object, the discriminating mental consciousness associated with memory. It can arise later, similar to the object that arose previously. Therefore, it cannot be maintained that memory arises, that is, that the object was previously cognized by consciousness.
If it is like in a dream, consciousness can arise without an object upon awakening.
If so, just as people know that the consciousness in a dream lacks an object, they should also know that the consciousness upon awakening lacks an object.
Since this is not the case, we know that the objects seen upon awakening are different from those seen in a dream.
Moreover, there is a sense of continuation in a dream, which is not so upon awakening. It is not the case that all [objects] lack an object.
Answer:
This statement is not conclusive.
The objects seen in a dream do not exist, but one cannot know this while still dreaming.
In this way, due to the confusion and habituation of false discrimination, worldly people see what is not a real object as if it were seen in a dream, and consider it to be real.
Upon awakening, it is not so. One can truly understand that the objects in a dream do not exist.

In the same way, when a practitioner cultivates the supramundane path of elimination and attains non-discriminating cognition, entering the stage of insight into the non-established truth and attaining enlightenment, at that time, the non-discriminating cognition and the subsequently attained pure mundane cognition see the six sense objects as truly non-existent in accordance with principle, and this meaning is equal.

If the six consciousnesses of sentient beings arise resembling the six sense objects due to the transformation of one's own continuity, but do not actually arise from the sense objects, then how can it be said that sentient beings have right and wrong concentrations due to associating with good and evil friends and listening to the correct and false two teachings?
How can this be established?
If what is relied upon and taught truly does not exist.
Because of the mutual predominance, the two cognitions are rightly and wrongly concentrated.
All sentient beings have two kinds of cognitive concentrations that are established, either rightly concentrated or wrongly concentrated, because of the mutual predominance of cognition.
Mutual means that oneself and others together accomplish the affairs of oneself and others.
Therefore, because the power of the continuity of a separate consciousness is superior, the power of the continuity of a separate consciousness arises, not from external objects.

If, like the consciousness in a dream, there is no object, and the consciousness in the waking state is also like this, then how is it that the two people in a dream and the two people in the waking state, when they perform good and evil, have different future fruits of love and hatred?
The future fruit is not the same, because the dream consciousness is destroyed by sleep.
This is the correct cause that makes the dream mind have no retribution. That is to say, because it is destroyed by drowsiness, the mind is weak and cannot form good or evil karma.
Question:
If everything is only consciousness, then there is no body or speech.
How is it that animals such as cows and sheep die when not harmed by butchers?
If their death is not caused by butchers, how can butchers obtain the sin of killing?
Answer:
The matter of death is accomplished here by the transformation of the consciousness of another,
Just as the loss of mind of another is caused by the power of the mind of ghosts and so forth.
Just as ghosts and spirits, due to the transformation of their minds, cause others to lose memory, have dreams, or become possessed by ghosts, and so forth, various transformations are accomplished.
Moreover, there are such things due to the mental vows of those with spiritual powers.
Just as King ÅšrÄ«sena had a dream, due to the mental vow of MahÄkÄtyÄyana.
Moreover, due to the angry mind of the ascetic Ä€rÄá¸a, King BimbisÄra saw frightening things.
In this way, by the transformation of another's consciousness, one can sever another's life-force.
For this reason, the continuity of the same type is severed, and this is called death. This meaning should be understood.
Moreover:
How is the DÄndaka forest empty and desolate due to the anger of the sages?

If it is not accepted that the death of beings is due to the dominant influence of the transformation of another's consciousness, the World-Honored One established mental punishment as the greatest offense, and asked the elder UpÄli:
Elder!
Have you ever heard
How can the DÄndaka forest, the KÄliá¹…ga forest, and the Madhyama forest be empty and pure?
The elder replied:
Gautama!
I have heard that it was due to the anger of the sages.
If the mind is severely punished for great offenses, how can that be accomplished?
If you hold that it is because the ghosts and spirits love and respect the sages, they kill the beings here, not because of the sages' angry minds.
If so, how is it that the mind is severely punished for this karma, more severely than the heavy punishment of body and speech?
Because of the angry minds of the sages, so many beings died, so the mind is severely punished and becomes a great offense.
If everything is only consciousness, do those with the supernormal power of knowing others' minds know others' minds or not?
If so, what is the reason?
If they do not know, how can they attain the supernormal power of knowing others' minds?
If they do know, how can it be said that consciousness has no objects?
How can the knowledge of those with the supernormal power of knowing others' mindsğŸ”½not be like its object?
Because of knowing one's own mind, one does not know the Buddha's realm.
How is the realm of the knowledge of others' minds not like this?
Because of the absence of knowledge.
Just as the essence of the inexpressible is accomplished, the Buddha's realm is like this, because it cannot be known.
These two realms are not like this, because they are not manifested in this way, and because the discrimination of the grasper and the grasped has not yet ceased.
The principle of consciousness-only is endless, and the categories of discernment are extremely profound and bottomless.
Having accomplished the principle of consciousness-only, I compose according to my ability,
In accordance with principle and in accordance with measure, the inconceivable realm of the Buddhas and others.
We make all efforts, but cannot conceive of this principle, because this principle is not the object of discursive thought.
Who can thoroughly penetrate this realm?
It is the realm of the Buddhas.
Why is it so?
Because the World-Honored Buddhas have unobstructed knowledge of all dharmas, this realm is seen only by the Buddhas in accordance with measure and in accordance with principle.
Vasubandhu Bodhisattva completed the treatise on Consciousness Only.

Cultivating the path is not shared with others, able to expound the unsurpassed meaning,
I bow my head to the principle of the Great Vehicle, and will now discuss the establishment and refutation.
Cultivated by immeasurable Buddhas, eliminating hindrances and the fundamental,
The nature of consciousness-only is tranquil, but inferior people do not enjoy it.
In reality, there are no external objects, because consciousness arises resembling objects,
Just like a person with blurred vision sees two moons and so forth.
Place and time are all uncertain, there is no continuity and uncertainty,
All activities are not accomplished, if there is only consciousness and no objects.
The meaning of definite place and so forth is established, like a dream, like hungry ghosts,
The continuity is uncertain, all see the same river of pus and so forth.
Just like in a dream, harmful actions are done, and next, like in hell,
All see the wardens and experience the harm together.
Just like animals reborn in the heavens, in hell there is no mixed path,
Because the retribution of suffering in hell cannot be experienced by them.
Because of the karma of sinful people, they give rise to things resembling wardens, etc.,
If you allow that they transform, why not allow it for them?
The perfuming of karma in the consciousness, grasping the result as arising externally,
Why is the result not spoken of in the place of perfuming?ğŸ”½The form and other sense bases are taught to be in the conditioned, in order to transform those who grasp the self,
Because of following the specific meaning, it is taught like the teaching of the magically created beings.
The consciousness arises from its own seeds, appearing as if it were an external object,
In order to establish the internal and external sense bases, the Buddha taught these two.
If others, relying on this teaching, can enter into the non-self of persons,
By the separate teaching that can eliminate, one enters the emptiness of dharmas through discrimination.
External objects and atoms are neither the same nor different,
because their aggregation is also not an object, and atoms are not established.
At one time, the six are aggregated, and atoms form the six directions.
If the six are in the same place, the aggregate size is like an atom.
If atoms do not combine, who combines them in the aggregate?
Moreover, without spatial division, atoms do not form an aggregate.
If an object has spatial division, it should not form a single object.
How about shadow and obstruction?
If the same, there are not two.
If one, without sequential movement, all are without attainment of what has been and what has not been attained,
and also without separate categories of many events, which are also difficult to see in detail.
The verifying cognition is like in a dream. At that time, like the verifying cognition,
at that time, objects are not seen. How can objects be verified?
As it is said, the consciousness resembling sense objects arises from this and retains them,
The sense objects in dreams do not exist, but before awakening one cannot know this.
Because they mutually enhance each other, the two consciousnesses are in right and wrong samÄdhis,
The consciousness in dreams is destroyed by sleep, the future fruits are not the same.
Due to the transformation of other consciousnesses, the matter of death is accomplished here,
Just like others losing their minds and so forth, due to the power of the minds of ghosts and so forth.
How is the DÄndaka forest empty and desolate due to the sages' anger?
The heavy punishment of great sins, if so, how is it accomplished?
The knowledge of those with the supernormal power of knowing others' minds is not like the object, how is it?
Because it knows its own mind, it does not know like the Buddha's realm.
Having accomplished the principle of consciousness only, I compose according to my own ability,
In accordance with principle and in accordance with measure, the inconceivable realm of the Buddhas and so forth.
